12.91.text: As a little girl, I always imagined

15.21.text: I would one day run away.

17.55.text: From the age of six on,

19.01.text: I kept a packed bag with some clothes

21.46.text: and cans of food tucked away

22.99.text: in the back of a closet.

24.98.text: There was a deep restlessness in me,

27.60.text: a primal fear that I would fall prey

30.15.text: to a life of routine and boredom.

32.93.text: And so, many of my early memories involved

35.53.text:
intricate daydreams where
I would walk across borders,

40.47.text: and meet all kinds of strange people

42.53.text: living unconventional lives on the road.

45.58.text: Years have passed, but many of the adventures

48.16.text: I fantasized about as a child --

52.52.text: between worlds other than my own —

54.52.text: have become realities through my work

58.69.text: But no other experience has felt as true

63.74.text: as living amongst and documenting the lives

66.46.text: of fellow wanderers across the United States.

73.91.text: a different kind of American dream

83.20.text: the vagabond is a creature from the past.

86.29.text: The word "hobo" conjures up an old

90.03.text: of a weathered old man covered in coal,

92.53.text: legs dangling out of a boxcar,

94.94.text: but these photographs are in color,

103.38.text: seeing sides of America that no one else

110.76.text: travel the steel and asphalt arteries

115.11.text:
By day, they hop freight trains,
stick out their thumbs,

118.30.text: and ride the highways with anyone

123.17.text: By night, they sleep beneath the stars,

125.50.text: huddled together with their packs of dogs,

128.18.text: cats and pet rats between their bodies.

131.89.text: Some travelers take to the road by choice,

137.10.text:
and university degrees in exchange 
for a glimmer of adventure.

141.03.text: Others come from the underbelly of society,

144.28.text: never given a chance to mobilize upwards:

147.32.text: foster care dropouts, teenage runaways escaping

153.84.text: Where others see stories of privation

160.69.text: through the prism of liberation and freedom.

164.27.text: They'd rather live off of the excess

166.48.text: of what they view as a wasteful consumer society

169.43.text: than slave away at an unrealistic chance

174.91.text: They take advantage of the fact

178.55.text: up to 40 percent of all food ends up in the garbage

182.37.text: by scavenging for perfectly good produce

187.68.text: They sacrifice material comforts in exchange

190.05.text: for the space and the time to explore

194.49.text: to dream, to read, to work on music, art and writing.

199.37.text: But there are many aspects to this life

204.24.text: No one loses their inner demons

208.08.text: Addiction is real, the elements are real,

213.45.text: and anyone who has lived on the streets can attest

216.11.text: to the exhaustive list of laws

222.11.text: Who here knows that in many cities

223.94.text: across the United States it is now illegal

228.62.text: to wrap oneself in a blanket,

232.01.text: to sleep in your own car,

234.74.text: to offer food to a stranger?

238.10.text: I know about these laws because I've watched

241.66.text: were hauled off to jail or received citations

247.92.text: Many of you might be wondering why anyone

250.08.text: would choose a life like this,

251.79.text: under the thumb of discriminatory laws,

257.27.text: picking up seasonal jobs here and there.

260.52.text: The answer to such a question is as varied

263.03.text: as the people that take to the road,

265.57.text: but travelers often respond with a single word:

271.28.text: Until we live in a society where every human

274.79.text: is assured dignity in their labor

276.86.text: so that they can work to live well,

280.85.text: there will always be an element of those

282.76.text: who seek the open road as a means of escape,

285.89.text: of liberation and, of course, of rebellion.
